qas.question: What was he known as soon after he died?
How does the Eastern Orthodox Church refer to him?
What do the Protestants call him?

What day is he celebrated in the Eastern Orthodox Church?

context: Nonetheless, within a few years of his death, Gregory of Nazianzus called him the "<a0_0><b10_0>Pillar of the Church<b10_0/><a0_0/>". His writings were well regarded by all Church fathers who followed, in both the West and the East, who noted their rich devotion to the Word-become-man, great pastoral concern, and profound interest in monasticism. Athanasius is counted as one of the four great Eastern Doctors of the Church in the Roman Catholic Church. In the Eastern Orthodox Church, he is labeled the "<a1_0><b11_0>Father of Orthodoxy<b11_0/><a1_0/>". Some Protestants label him "<a2_0><b12_0>Father of the Canon<b12_0/><a2_0/>". Athanasius is venerated as a Christian saint, whose feast day is <a3_0><b5_0><b8_0><b13_0>2 May<b13_0/><b8_0/><b5_0/><a3_0/> in Western Christianity, <b7_0>15 May<b7_0/> in the Coptic Orthodox Church, and <a4_0><b6_0><b9_0><b14_0>18 January<b14_0/><b9_0/><b6_0/><a4_0/> in the other Eastern Orthodox Churches. He is venerated by the Oriental and Eastern Orthodox Churches, the Roman Catholic Church, the Lutherans, and the Anglican Communion.
